thread.title: Trucking Acquisitions Put New Spotlight on Fleet Values

author: Erica E. Phillips
title: Trucking Acquisitions Put New Spotlight on Fleet Values

organizations.name: trucking acquisitions put new spotlight on fleet values

text:
0 COMMENTS Trucking companies newly flush with cash are stepping up strategies to grow through acquisitions, but they’re finding new challenges in financial reporting along the road.
Earlier this month, Iowa-based trucker Heartland Express Inc. HTLD 1.58% dismissed its auditing firm of 16 years, KPMG LLP, citing differences over internal communication and procedures after the firm’s acquisition last July of Interstate Distributor Co.
The apparent dust-up highlights a key issue facing a trucking market where mergers and acquisitions are heating up: the value truckers place on the equipment and the business they’re acquiring.
“There has to be some consistency in the methodology of how you value things when you buy them,” said Mike Regan, chief of relationship development with logistics and freight management consultancy TranzAct Technologies Inc.
In the $113 million deal last July, Heartland acquired IDC’s fleet of 1,350 trucks. At the time, Heartland said in a statement the “purchase accounting remains ongoing” and that the value of IDC’s assets, including the trucks, “could be reduced versus the values previously recorded by IDC due to shorter useful lives.”

Heartland said in the SEC filing that Grant Thornton LLP would become the company’s public accounting firm, replacing KPMG. Chris Strain, Heartland’s chief financial officer, didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment. Representatives for KPMG didn’t return messages seeking comment.
As M&A heats up and far-flung truck fleets attempt to integrate their operations, auditors will be paying close attention to details like the valuation of equipment assets, analysts said.
A series of recent acquisitions by Roadrunner Transportation Systems Inc. led to wide-ranging accounting problems. Roadrunner announced last year that it had to restate the last three years of earnings reports, and this week the company said it would be postponing its latest quarterly report, sending its stock price plummeting.
“There’s heightened sensitivity among analysts because the Roadrunner fiasco kind of opened some eyes,” Mr. Regan said.
‘ There has to be some consistency in the methodology of how you value things when you buy them. ’
—Mike Regan, TranzAct Technologies. Since last July, the Interstate business has driven up Heartland’s operating expenses, tamping down its margins.
In the fourth quarter of 2017, the firm’s operating income was down $11 million, to $9.9 million, from the same period a year earlier, despite an 18.3% improvement in revenue. Net profit nearly tripled to $38.6 million, including a $32.8 million gain from the new tax law.
Asset sales appear to have helped keep Heartland’s finances on firm footing, according to Barclays Capital Inc. In a note to investors Tuesday,
Barclays analysts said Heartland historically led the industry in profitability but its acquisitions of Gordon Trucking in 2013 and IDC last year have cut margins nearly in half, even “with a sizable contribution from gains on sales of equipment.” Strong consumer and industrial spending, as well as a rapidly-tightening supply of truck capacity, has driven up the value of those and other used trucks.
